episode.title: McDonald v. Board of Election Comm'rs of Chicago

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 68, Sam L. McDonald ET AL, appellants versus Board of Election Commissioners of Chicago ET AL.
Mr. Bass?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
This is an appeal from an order of the three-judge Court in Chicago, dismissing a suit for declaratory judgment and injunction.

The suit was filed by two pre-trial detainees from Chicago, Cook County jail, on behalf of themselves and all of the persons similarly situated who are registered qualified voters but who are unable to get to the polls on election date because they are incarcerated, either without bail or because they lack the funds to post to monetary bail.
The suit sought a judgment declaring that the Illinois --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In other words these are not people who have been convicted of crime, is that it?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: They're just awaiting trial?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Correct.

The suits sought a judgment declaring that the Illinois statutes applicable to absentee voting are unconstitutional and so far as they preclude the granting of absentee ballots to pre-trial detainees confined in the county of their residents.
A timely notice of appeal was filed from the judgement of the District Court.
The jurisdictional statement was filed in February.
In April, this Court grants a leave to proceed in 0139 and postponed the issue of jurisdiction until the hearing on the merits.
So, I will turn first to the issue of jurisdiction.
Under Section 1253 of Title 28, appeals lie directly to the Supreme Court from an order denying an injunction and a civil action which is required to be heard by a three-judge Court.

We therefore turn to Section 2281 of the judicial code which provides the three-judge district Court is required where an injunction is sought to restrain the enforcement, operation, or execution of a state statute by restraining the action of an officer of the state.
So there are three ingredients here.
First, that injunction must be sought, that was true in this case.
Second, that there is a state statute or general state wide application.
That's what we have in this case.
Third, that we have a state officer or pursuant to the decisions of this Court, a local officer functioning pursuant to a state wide policy performing a state function.

Now under Illinois law, as far as absentee ballots are concerned, the Chicago Board of Election Commissioners has the same responsibility as the county clerk in another county or anybody else who was charged with the duty of furnishing absentee ballots.

Indeed, Section 19-2 of the election code which appears on page 15 of our brief states on the ninth line of the provision that the elector make application to the county clerk or were existing to the Board of Election Commissioners or other officer or officers charged with the duty of furnishing ballots for such election in his voting district.

So that the fact that the Board of Election Commissioners here are the defendants is not relevant because their function is a state wide function, they perform the same function with respect to absentee ballots as the officers in the other counties and localities.
Nor is this case moot at this time.
It is true that the two named representative plaintiffs are not in the Cook County jail awaiting trial.

Mr. Byrd was discharged a week after the election at his preliminary hearing and Mr. McDonald went to trial, it was a hang jury and he subsequently pleaded to a reduce charge of manslaughter which is a bailable offense.
However, since this is a class action and was found to be so by the trial court and I referred to page 30 of the record, where the three-judge Court says plaintiffs and the class they represent are.

The fact that this is a class action means that the fact that the named plaintiffs are not members of the class a more is not fatal as this Court indicated a month after the jurisdictional statement was filed to this case and the case was Lee versus Washington which involved the desegregation of the Alabama jails.
This Court --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Have you made implicate -- have an intervener so you'd have a named party?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: No effort has made -- was made to name any persons but I presume and I would respectfully ask the Court to respect the judgement of the District Court that this was a class action and that there are in the county jail prior to each election, a certain number of persons for which --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: As I understand it, you say that it was a class action, I'm wondering what is it now?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: What is it at this moment?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Well, Mr. Justice Marshall, the problem is that the class really cannot be seen very clearly until right before an election because it's very difficult to predict exactly who will be a pre-trial detainee on the day of election.

One could ascertain with some degree of certainty perhaps that we go to before the election exactly which persons, which named persons would be pre-trial detainees unable to get to the polls on election day and because this class is rather fluid, it's really impossible to identify any names except right before an election but I think the three-judge court below recognized that there surely must be a number of persons who are registered qualified voters in jail on the day of election.

Incidentally, the Cook County jail has about 1800 inmates, 2/3 of which awaiting trial, so that then there must be some number of person although they cannot be identified except right near an election.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So, it's going to be someone who has just been put in jail the day or the two in court too before who will not be able to vote under the ordinary --

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Vague questions because --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: provision governing all absentee voters.
There must -- there's a minimum time in advance within which you have to --

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- apply for ballot, is there?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: And we're not attacking that provision on making application within a certain amount of time as being --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Because actually of general applicability to call absentee voters --

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- is that it?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Well, it's a reasonable provision.
I don't think that there is anything unreasonable about requiring submissions perhaps to do ballots to be made in a certain time because there are some administers.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, let say -- I don't quite -- really, we're not here to decide what's reasonable or unreasonable, are we?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Well, I'm not assailing the provisions regarding time.
We are assailing the substantive provisions as to who can take the ballot.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Not because they're unreasonable, are you?
You're assailing him because you submit that they violate the Equal Protection Clause --

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- amendment of the United States constitution?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: I will turn to that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But does the class include people who are convicted without sentence?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: No, they're unconvicted.
We use the word unsentenced a few times but the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The court below, did the District Court set any sentence?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: The --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They should pass the standard to represent all unsentenced inmates.
I supposed that could be under or will be the same problem, wouldn't they?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: There was some loose language, we intended and was clear but the time were litigating this, we were dealing with the pre-trial detainees rather than persons who were between that period of conviction and sentence.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Do you make any due process argument?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Well frankly, I would like to allude to an argument which might be considered a due process one I haven't raised it the brief but we raised it with respect to answering the Board of Election Commissioners argument about the fact that persons who can be deprived of liberty cannot assert privilege.
In other words, if it is a due process argument, it would be that the mere fact the person is detained prior to trial does not mean that he could be deprived the all rights.
I would like to turn to the merits of the case at this time.

This case was originally argued on a rational basis test but recently this Court decided the Williams versus Rhodes which seems to have put the right to vote on a First Amendment basis and it appears to us that Williams versus Rhodes makes clear that the right to -- that there is a relation between voting and political expression which is protected by the First Amendment and secondly, that the state must show a compelling state interest in imposing heavy burdens upon the right to vote.

Now, in this case, it's not very clear, it's not clear at all whether there are any legitimate state interests who are compelling to justify the denial of the right to vote to a person whose awaiting trial.

It would appear that the most that the election board could say would be that there's an administrative convenience in not having to dispense too many absentee ballots, but it seems to me that the mere fact that it's a few more absentee ballots to give out does not justify deprivation of such a fundamental right.
The board of election commission has taken the position in its brief that voting is a privilege or the voting by absentee ballot is a privilege rather than array.
And it seems to me that by calling something a privilege doesn't mean that the state can arbitrarily deny it to you.

Surely, if absentee ballots were dispensed on the basis of race, I don't think this Court would hesitate to say that that would be a denial of equal protection of the law, merely because absentee balloting may be considered a privilege by the state, and the District Court in Brown versus Post which we referred to in our reply brief held that where the Board of -- where the elections people went to the nursing home, the white nursing homes and not the black nursing homes that that was a denial of equal protection of the law and in giving out absentee ballots.
We submit that the mere fact that there is an absentee ballot rather than voting in person does not justify such a distinction.
Now, the Board of Election Commissioners raises the question, “need prisoners be afforded privileges when they can be denied liberty.”

I think this is perhaps the first case that this Court has had an opportunity to determine, whether there are any conditions or consequences of pretrial detention which may be considered constitutionally impermissible.

We must recognize that no matter how much bail reform occurs there is just going to be a number of people are going to be incarcerated prior to trial and it seems to me that we must address ourselves to the consequences of the pretrial detention.
I don't think it's a basic proposition one could say that the mere fact the man is detained prior to trial means you can do anything you want with him.
I think he's entitled to certain minimum standards of decency.
I think that if the state attempts to deny certain basic rights, they must show a compelling interest.
Now, what kind of compelling interest might be shown?
Perhaps institutions have certain rules regarding persons who visit.
Considerations of institutional security of course are parallel.
I think this Court in Lee versus Washington indicated that it's decision in no way suggested that the warden couldn't make allowances for institutional security.
But nowhere in the record of this case or in any case have I ever heard that inmate voting by absentee ballots or some -- have -- going to disrupt the routine of an institution.
There's nothing to suggest that it does.
I think common sense would suggest that perhaps morale would be a lift when somebody votes from behind bars.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You have an opportunity to look at the -- at the absentee ballot and laws of any of the other states?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Yes I did, I made a state by state canvass.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What'd you find out with respect to --

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Well, I found out that --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- just as right as your clients are.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Every state grants absentee ballots to the servicemen who are abroad.
Two states seem to recognize the right of prisoners to vote.
Both of these states I have opinions of the Attorney General but I found no cases.
Most -- excuse me.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Go ahead.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Most of the states have varying provisions from physical disability to absence from various localities. For example, once -- the 12 states say that if you'll be absent from the precinct, you can get an absentee ballot.
Six states say if you're absent from the city, you get an absentee ballot.

One state, Louisiana says if you're absent from the parish, 23 states say if you're absent from the county, and five states say if you're absent from the state on Election Day, you can get an absentee ballot.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I don't -- some of the state limit the eligibility for absentee of the ballots to those who are going to be absent for specified reasons?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Some of them break it down and say absence in the county for business reasons.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: For business but not -- but not for a vacation, isn't that true?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: That's for some of them do.
That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So they will require the absence to be on kind of business, others --

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Some do.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- limit it or to use to at least to military and student?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And others to physical incapacity to be there?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is that true?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Now, we're not --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But there are sorts of -- aren't there all sorts of classifications --

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- made by each one of the states or at least by the typical state.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: That's right, Illinois has an interesting classification.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: There's no state is there that -- that just says, if you're not going to be here for any reason.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: I think Maine says that.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Maine does say that.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: I think that's the only state that does it.
Now, we're not suggesting that everybody who wants an absentee ballot can have one.
There are certain limitations which we recognize as constitutionally.

For example, the mere fact that a mother who has children or a breadwinner who has a job with long hours can't get to the polls, may find it inconvenient, we feel that we're not submitting that that's a denial of the constitution but what we have is something more than that.
We have the state putting the man into disability.
They have the state judge putting the man in jail on Election Day.
And we have another state agency which refuses the ballot and together that's joint state action which effectively deprives a man of the rights to vote.
So it seems to me that the situation of the prisoners can't be distinguished and any decision in their favor would not necessarily have to require that everybody in the world get an absentee ballot.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Do you have that state by state analysis to which you just referred in your brief?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: We did not include it on the brief Your Honor, Justice Fortas.
I would be glad to submit that by way of a supplemental brief if I think I believe to do so.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: It would be helpful if you do that.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: I will.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: It's alright.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: In terms of legitimate state interest, perhaps it might be urged that the takeover theory that all of the inmates voting together might outweigh a community.

But in the first place, the inmates would vote in the count -- in the precinct in which they lived prior to becoming member of the jail population so that they would not vote in the precinct where the jail was located but they would be in disperse from the various precincts in which they come.
In any event, I think that the takeover theory was rejected by this Court in the Carrington case.

Now, we would submit that the -- that this case can be decided on a number of theories. One theory would be that the granting of the absentee ballot to a person who is jailed in another county or denial of an absentee ballot of a person jailed in the county of his residence is absolutely irrational.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Doesn't the proposition that you're advancing here lead us to invalidate an awful lot of these state laws to which you've referred.
That is to say why is it -- you make the distinction that here the prisoner is being kept away from the polls by a state action, is that right?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: That's correct, that's my second theory.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Huh?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: That's my second theory that this case goes off on the fact that the state granted him unable to get to the polls.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, I suppose when you're talking about what is -- what is primary cause (Inaudible) and so on, what is your first reason?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Well, the first one is that the classifications that the state of Illinois has employed are not rational or based upon compelling state interest.
That is that the Board of Election Commissioners or the state has failed to show in what respect is a legitimate state interest that requires the denial of absentee ballots to this --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, that's the one that would require -- that would lead at least by the treacherous path of strict logic to the conclusion that we have to examine everyone of these state laws and say that it's not rational or reasonable for a state to say that you can get an absentee ballot if you're out of town on business but not if you're out of -- not up here -- out of the state or some other reason.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Well, I would say yes except using the compelling state interest theory that the state would probably be able to show in a large number of those situations involving their inconvenience rather than impossibility that there is a legitimate -- that there is a compelling state interest, whereas in this case, I don't think that they can show that.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: How about the -- under the laws that exist, how about the man who is physically incapacitated, the man or woman who was physically incapacitated for medical reason?
If he is in the county, does -- he can vote absentee again.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Physically incapacitated I believe the -- about perhaps half of the states.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I'm not talking about Chicago, about Illinois.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Well, if a man who is physically incapacitated and he can produce a certificate of a physician which the Illinois statute requires and if he is inside the county, he can get an absentee ballot.
These provision -- and also, if he can show that because of religious groups, he can get -- there was also a way --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And those are the only -- those are the only two classifications of people who are in the county on election day is those who are physically incapacitated that is medically incapacitated or those who are observing a religious holiday who may get an absentee ballots, is that correct?
That's the way I read the --

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: There was one classification that was added by the legislature at the last minute which escape the attorney's and the three-judge court in this case and that was a judge of election who is working on election day --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: On a different precinct, yeah.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: -- on a precinct other than his own but those are the classes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: In addition to that, I suppose your veterans can vote, can't they?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: The veterans?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Who are out of the state?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Well, members of the Armed Forces.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's what I mean.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's what I mean.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: And many other people who are out of the state?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: That's right.
There use to be a special provision for servicemen which was article 20 but since the provision was added, anybody out of the county, that automatically swallowed up that group.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How about if they're in a camp in the state?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: As long as they're out of the county that's all at least are required.
The Board of Election Commissioners will give them an absentee ballot.
And even if a man is in jail if he's in the county other than the county of his residence, presumably, he'll get an absentee ballot too.

So it seems to me that it's difficult to say that this refusal to give absentee ballots to these class of persons is justified by considerations of institutional security, because of that would show, the legislature would have said I hope that we make a finding that because of the routine of the jail, it would be so disruptive that no absentee ballot should go to prisons.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, you don't have a case in which the state has explicitly said, we are going to deny the right of an absentee ballot to people who are in jail.

You have rather than that -- you have a case in which the state has said, we are going to grant right of absentee ballots to people who are even though they're going to be in this county on Election Day to the following two groups into these two groups, three groups into these three groups only.

Those who are medically incapacitated, those who are celebrating their religious holiday, and those who because they're judges or poll watches or something, or going to be at another pre-voting place.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: And those who'll be out of the county.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And those are the only three groups to whom we're going to grant the right of absentee voting even though they are in the county on Election Day.

You do no not have a case where the state at least any as explicit are considered kind of a way has said that we're going to deny the right of absentee ballots even though we grant it to everybody else, we're going to deny it for those who are in jail.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: That's correct Mr. Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You don't have a case to that kind of discrimination at all.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: It's a denial by implication rather than expressed denial but I think that that makes this case stronger because had the legis --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: uppose a business -- medically incapacitated, wouldn't he be allowed to vote?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Judge Lynch said that he could.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Judge Lynch in the first McDonald case said.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I mean, wouldn't that be a reasonable interpretation of the statute?
It doesn't say that a medically incapacitated man who's in prison will not to be granted the right to vote.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: I would say as to that to --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I would think that your prisoners would be as medically incapacitated like the class A created would come under that statute and be entitled to have an absentee ballot.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: He might be able to but that does get into that causation question as to whether the cause has in ability is the fact that he is sick or the fact that he is incarcerated.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, that might some -- there's someone that might be then medically incapacitated.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: I think if he had his physician certificate under those circumstances that the Board of Election Commissioners would probably give him the ballot.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yeah, that's what I thought.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: I think so.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So that that involves his business?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: No, it just bars those that are well, that are not religious that are unconsecrated in the county of their own residence and it seems to me that that type of classification doesn't make any sense and is certainly is not justified by any compelling state interest.
I tried to figure out, if there were any, I looked at the brief of the Board of Election Commissioner as unable to find any.
It seems to me what the State of Illinois is done here and it gives this Court a unique opportunity to get into the area of absentee ballots is --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You need that.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Well, I think that it's an important one because absentee ballots have been with us since the civil war and they've become a very convenient means of voting.
It's not like in the old day where it was considered such a new process that this Court, state Courts was tracking them down.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What's -- what happen -- what does an Illinois election official say if somebody shows up to the polling place and not with his certificate of a physician but certificate of the ward which states people did, what does a -- what do the election official say?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Well, they said --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It's not of the polling place for that's the absentee ballots they might think.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Well, they said in this case that you don't have the right certificate.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But would it be a violation of the Illinois law and say didn't, send them, give them out absentee ballot?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Well, as I understand Illinois law, it's true that the provisions of absentee ballots are permissive but it seems to me that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But didn't this man say that I refuse to do this, I refuse to issue these ballots because that would be subject to criminal penalties if I did?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: He said he would be.
I don't know if there's any express provision that says if you give an absentee ballots to other persons that'll be a violation of the law.
I think the Election Board probably assumes that if he gives ballots to persons other than those named expressly that this would be a violation of Illinois law.
But as I read the statutes, there is nothing that says, don't give it to these people, it just doesn't say, give it to these people.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, how can a person who is in jail know that he won't be out in time to vote if he is jail and hadn't been convicted?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: It's his next continued Court date.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: It's his next continued Court date if that continued Court date.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Maybe a bit bail or maybe you represent him and get him on his own recognizance.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: It's -- that's the same situation as a person who thinks he's going out of town on business.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now, how about a fellow who will know not quite because he's not being held and released by somebody else.
He's theoretically master his destiny.
How about a person who's been convicted of a misdemeanor and is in jail, now, you're not, are you disqualified under Illinois law if you have been convicted of misdemeanor?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: No you're not.
It's only --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And suppose the Court has been convicted of a misdemeanor --

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: He'd be similarly situated.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- and he's in jail, the same principle would apply to him, would it?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Yes it would and it would apply also to persons who are convicted of civil crimes, non support or contempt.

It seems to me that if it's anything other than conviction of a felony and if -- or from this crime, you're not disenfranchised explicitly but you do run into the problems since you can't get to the polls.
Are you entitled to that mechanism which the State of Illinois has setup?

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, if they're going to vote, I suppose they don't have a right to have to listen to political arrange appeals to their better nature and judgment.

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: I would say it to the extent to which the state can show a compelling interest in limiting that the number of persons that can come in campaign, subject to the certain restrictions which are atoned to the institutional framework that the state can refuse certain rights of the persons who want to campaign but it seems to me as a basic preposition is to whether or not there are any restraints at all.
It seems to me that the state must show that compelling state interest in the case where they seek to restrict a vote.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Some of the Western States, there are counties that are larger than some of the eastern states and suppose a man went from one end of the county where he lives to another end of that county to live in a -- say in a hotel and he would be there over Election Day, would you say that it was -- it was unconstitutional not to send him a ballot under the law that you have in?

turn.speaker: stanley_a_bass
turn.label: Mr. Stanley A. Bass
turn.text: Well, I would say to the extent to which he's really the -- really has control over his situation that that would mean, not like the fact in this situation.
I recognize that there are problems of judgment in determining when the state has satisfied its burden of showing a compelling state interest.
But it seems to me that where we have persons like persons in the army or persons in jail.
That person is precluded by an official act from getting to the polls and he would have to break the law.
He would actually have to escape jail or go AWOL in order to try to cast his vote.
And we submit that under those certain circumstances, the state must show a very compelling interest in order to justify giving him the ballot which can be easily be voted by mail.
I wanted to add one last matter and that is that we have a presumption of innocence under the law.
However, in reality, this presumption can be willed away by a lot of circumstances.
For example, we're beginning to discover that conditions of pretrial detention in very many institutions across the country are a lot lower standard than we would consider human decency it requires.
And it seems to me that unless this Court is willing to say that there are some limitations, there are some rights that you just can't take away from the man merely because he's awaiting trial.
He's presumed to be innocent.

In order to give full filthy the presumption of innocence, the Court has got to say that it was a very important right the state must show a compelling state interest in order to deprive the man of that right.
I'd like to receive a few moments of time to --

section.heading: Argument of Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You may resume.
Mr. Kusper?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice Warren, may it please the Court.
Mr. Beemsterboer, Mr. Bass.
Counsel for petitioners, excuse me, has consistently stated this case in the negative, both at the trial level and before this Court.
His constant statement has been, the state must show a compelling state interest in depriving this small group of persons of a supposed constitutional right to an absentee ballot.
I would care to phrase it in another way for the Court.

The state has extended to large ascertainable groups of people the privilege of absentee balloting, the privilege of the ballot, excuse me, the right of the ballot has been constitutionally guaranteed but the privilege of casting it under conditions imposed by the state which are reasonable by an absentee ballot, I think its just that, a privilege and so the state of Illinois has extended to large discernable ascertainable groups of people the right of voting by absentee ballot.
Large numbers of people leave the community on business or for whatever other reason and leave the county.
In 1968, some 15000 applications were received from persons at the Board of Election Commissioners.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And necessary for one who's on your side?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is it necessary for one who wants to be on your side, try to put it on the basis on the difference between the privilege and a right.

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: I don't think so Mr. Justice --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I would think it makes up

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: I don't think so at all but rather than confused right with privilege, let's talk about what it really is.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- take care of one evil have to take care of every possible evil that anyone can conceive off?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: No, certainly not.
I think a state legislature in attacking any kind of a problem or any kind of an evil may take it that the entire evil at one time may take it step by step.
It may progress from one phase of the problem to another phase of the problem and make corrections as it has seen fit.

And in fact, in Illinois as the trial court below has pointed out, absentee balloting was instituted in 1917, at 3208 and it was modified again in 1944, expanded in 1955 and just in the 1967 session of the legislature, short time subsequent to the trial of this case, it extended absentee balloting to those persons who are judges of election who would serve outside the precinct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why were these people excluded?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Why were they excluded?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Justice Marshall, I don't know why they were excluded.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, don't you think the state should have some reason?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: I think the state has a reason for enacting a piece of legislation in --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Now, do you think --

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: -- the nature of absentee balloting.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you think the states obliged to tell somebody the reason you distinguish between prisoners awaiting trial outside the county and those inside the county.

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Prisoners awaiting trial outside the county Mr. Justice Marshall are outside of the county and fall into that class of persons granted the absentee ballot privilege --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Aren't these --

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Because they're out of the county.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, they're different because they're outside of the county?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But they're still awaiting trial by the state of Illinois?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So that much they are like but why draw the line there?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Because the state has taken affirmative action in granting the absentee ballots to groups of people.
It has by inadvertence or otherwise, I don't know if they had a reason for it, I certainly wouldn't know if they ever considered the problem.
It maybe that they never even thought of the problem.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Can you think of a reason?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Can I think of a reason?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Why they should not be granted an absentee ballot?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No, why the state made a difference a man in jail waiting for trial outside the county and a man waiting for trial inside the county.
When you finish that, I want to know the different between a man out on bail and a man who is incarcerated for not having the money for bail.

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Its my firm belief that the legislature in enacting absentee ballot legislation never considered the problem of persons present inside the county in a jail awaiting trial and persons outside of a county awaiting trial.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You mean he didn't know that?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: I don't know sir whether or not they knew about it.
There are 177 members of the Illinois House, there are 59 members of the Illinois Senate, I would not presume to know what they thought about it.
There is no history on the legislation available which would indicate to use whether or not they even considered the problem.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But that in mind as we've looked at this, can we say that we see no valid reason for distinguishing two man are charged with a crime, one has bail money, the other man has no bail money, they both committed the same crime, one can vote and the other one cannot.
Now, what reason is there for that distinction?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: I don't know of any reason at all Mr. Justice Marshall, I could not --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Aren't you obliged -- aren't you obliged to give us a -- something close to a reason?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: No I believe my burden sir under the language of the cases of this Court is first of all, to demonstrate that, Mr. Bass on behalf of petitioners has not carried his burden to show that there is unreasonable basis so that there is invidious discrimination, whether there is arbitrariness or capriciousness in the action of the legislature in enacting this particular legislation, and secondly, if the burden does shift to me to rational or justify the decision then its my burden to go forward with it and you asked me for a reason sir and I cannot give you a reason why a legislation beginning back in 1917 prior to the time of my birth sir, why that legislation did not contain some provision for these persons.
It is my sincere belief as I stated before that the legislature just not ever considered the problem.
Either A because it wasn't cognizant of it or B, nobody just took the time to bring it up.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But the legislature did consider the problem as to whether or not people in jail awaiting trial should or should not have an absentee ballot.
The legislature did consider that, didn't he?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: No sir, there is nothing in this record that would indicate that and there is nothing in the history of the legislation that would indicate it.

The physical incapacity that is discussed in -- is covered in the statute relates itself solely to the question of physical incapacity because of physical illness that properly attested to by the affidavit of the physician or of a Christian Science practitioner and there is nothing in the statute nor anything in the legislative history which would indicate that the legislature ever considered this and deliberately drew distinction between the two classes of persons.
All the considered was in the county and who's out.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Who did draw the distinction?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Bass is apparently drawn the distinction Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No, these people tried to file their absentee ballots and election commissioner said that they were not physically handicapped, isn't that what happened?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: The election commissioners and I was present at all times when this petitions for absentee ballot were presented.
The election commissioners being statutory creature is bound by statutory requirements in state of Illinois.
They have the ability to grant absentee ballots in those specified cases enumerated in the statute allowing the privilege of absentee voting.
When Mr. Bass came to our office with an affidavit and an application for a ballot with the affidavit of an assistant warden I believe it was in each case.
He did not comply with any of the permissive applications that were provided in the statute and therefore, the Board of Election Commissioners --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what is there -- what is there in the statute that this did not comply with?
Didn't he say they were physically for them to get that?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: They said sir that it was physically impossible for them to be in attendance at the polls and then they attached an affidavit of an assistant warden which says they couldn't leave the premises but they did not attach the affidavit of a doctor or a Christian Science practitioner which was what was required under the statute of Illinois, and therefore the board of election commissioners being purely ministerial at this point could not accept that application or that affidavit and could not within the meaning of the statute grant an absentee ballot to do so, would have been a violation of Illinois law under the Article 29 (a).

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But there's no question that this was state action?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: I don't think --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The action of the commissioners, no question about that.

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: The commissioners acted in pursuant to Illinois statute.
There is no question about the fact that they acted under Illinois law in their capacity as officers created by a statute in Illinois.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Were you advising them?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Yes I was sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that -- would you help me to draw his affidavit?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Was I advising whom, excuse me.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The election commissioners.

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: I was advising the election commissioners --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Would you help draw his affidavit?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Did I help draw the affidavit for the physically incapacitated people, no I did not sir, that is --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, for the election commissioner.

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: No, I did not, that is --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What is on page 26, as you named it, the end of it, 26 and 27 of the record?

And it says that I -- you say that I refused to authorize issuance of absentee ballots to the named plaintiffs rather than violate my statutory duty and you say that I will grant and that you will grant future applications only if forced to do so by compulsory process and --

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: That is the end of the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- if they did it and you say if they did it, you'd be subject to fine and imprisonment.

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.
I drew the affidavit for the Board of Election Commissioners that is correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So there is a law --

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: In the pleadings.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So there is a law in Illinois that if the election commissioner had issued this ballots, they'd had been put in jail, or fined.

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: There is a general provision Mr. Justice White.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You mean -- so therefore -- you're saying there is no state action that secludes these people getting --

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Well, there is a state statute that precludes it but they acted in denial of the petition for an absentee ballot pursuant to an otherwise state statute.
They just couldn't grant it because the state statute didn't let them grant it and it would subject to them to penalties if they had.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Am I right Mr. Kusper of the fact that this affidavit says is that it has to be denied just specific or affirmatively written on the election law of Illinois that absentee ballot shall be not given to the pre-trial detained.

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: It's not exactly what it says, Mr. Justice Brennan --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I know what it said but doesn't this affidavit have other fact?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: What it says is I can't do anything other than which is permitted to me to do under the laws of Illinois and there is no provision in the Absentee Balloting Act of Illinois which allows the Commissioner to grant application for an absentee ballot on a basis of these warden's affidavit.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What did Mr. Boseman mean when he said I will grant future application only when compelled to do so by composing possibly accordance to incumbent jurisdiction as I'm am done on three previous occasions?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Because we were ordered on three previous occasions by the Federal Court, Judge Lynch in both cases presiding and it was not a State Court it was a Federal Court which ordered us to do it and in pursuance to that kind of an order I think we have to act, it put us between the devil and the deep blue sea.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: He ordered you to do, why?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: You ordered us to give an absentee ballot to a particular prisoner on three different occasions, Norman Bonds and also McDonald on two occasions.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Your point is that if somebody come down with an affidavit saying I'm going to be in the county on election day but I'm going to be awfully busy because I'm going to taken care of my sister's sick child and can't get to the poll.

Then the Election Board could not under the law have granted that person an absentee ballot and if they've done so they would have been subjected to criminal penalty simply because there's no provision for that kind of a person voting absentees, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Absolutely correct, sir.
Absolutely, correct.
They can't give --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Your submission as I see it is something like this that the state provide -- the state accords the right to vote to everybody with certain exclusions.
These petitioner's -- these appellants presumably have a right to vote.
The state however provides a special procedure in certain limited classes that is to say absentee voting.
It does not provide a special procedure with respect to people who are endurance by awaiting trial or otherwise and your point is the state has no duty to do that.
Indeed, the state has no duty to extend the absentee voting alternative method across the board as to anybody, is that right?

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
turn.label: Mr. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr.
turn.text: Well, there can be a situation in which there is no absentee voting.
It isn't constitutionally provided for I agree.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That's what I'm saying that the state has no obligation to provide that the absentee voting alternative procedure --

turn.speaker: stanley_t_kusper_jr
